title: Coach Trip's Brendan Sheerin had to hide love away in early years fearing arrest

Considering his lifelong career in travel, it’s fitting that it was in an airport that Brendan Sheerin first had an inkling he was famous.

As the genial tour guide, who has been brightening up afternoons on Channel 4 since 2005, recalls, ‘The first time I realised, “Oooh my goodness, this is a popular programme,” was when all the immigration officers were like, “Hey, it’s Brendan from Coach Trip.”’

Before receiving a call out of the blue asking him to audition for the show, Brendan was a semi-retired tour guide working in Scarborough.

(Image: Ken McKay/ITV/Shutterstock)

‘Never in a million years did I think I’d actually get the job,’ he remembers.

Brendan, 60, is wearing a dark blue shirt and a warm smile when we meet.

As he offers us some luxury chocolates, it’s clear he has a knack for putting people at ease – which he’ll need as he corrals another bunch of passengers, including jungle queen Vicky Pattison and Steps star Ian ‘H’ Watkins, in the new series of Celebrity Coach Trip.

He happily admits he’s not always familiar with the celeb version’s roster of reality stars.

‘On many occasions I don’t know who they are because I don’t watch their type of programme,’ he says.

‘I prefer documentaries.

‘But I aways ask them a few questions about it.’

With participation being the name of the Coach Trip game, Brendan’s job is made much easier when people whole-heartedly embrace the concept.

‘My favourite passengers are always the ones who throw themselves into the activities 150% – whatever it is or whatever age they are.

‘Whether it’s abseiling or paragliding.’

‘The other end of the spectrum is when people have been on the coach a bit too long and start to get a bit blasé.

‘They take things for granted.

‘I’ll say, “This morning we’re going pottery making!” and they’ll go, “Ugggh.”

‘Do you know what I mean?

‘We can’t go gliding or up in aeroplanes every day!’ he laughs.

(Image: ENTERPRISE NEWS AND PICTURES)

As for whether he prefers shepherding regular people or celebs on the coach, Brendan muses that he enjoys helping Joe Public face their fear of heights through activities like abseiling.

But he adds with a mischievous glint in his eye, ‘With celebs it’s entirely different because if you ask them to dance they’ll dance for you, won’t they?’

He grew up in Leeds, but sun worshipper Brendan is now happily based in Spain.

‘I learnt Spanish when I went out to work as a courier.

‘It was only a summer job and then I ended up staying.

‘I’ve lived in Torremolinos for about 15 years, I love it,’ he beams.

‘I love the weather and it’s my little rest and unwind when I’m not doing Coach Trip.’

Brendan regularly socialises with friends and family, but lost his partner Les several years ago.

‘Yes, I’m still single,’ he says.

‘I’m widowed, really.

‘I had a lovely relationship with Les and we were together for 25 years.

‘We lived together in L’Estartit on the Costa Brava for a long time.

‘In the early days it was a bit dark because you had to be 21 to have a gay relationship.’

So Brendan’s thrilled to see the changes in society these days.

‘It does my heart good to see two boys holding hands.

‘A while ago I was on Regent Street and I saw these two boys and they saw me looking.

‘I said, “Do you know, I would have been arrested for doing that when I was young.”

‘They just said, “Thank you for standing up for gay rights,” because they know the older generation paved the way for the younger one.

‘So it gladdens my heart.’

(Image: (Channel 4 images must not be altered or manipulated in any way) Channel 4 Picture Publicity, Horseferry Road, London, SW1P 2TX)

Although some of the male Coach Trip passengers may be easy on the eye, Brendan is a true professional when he’s on the job.

‘There’s a time for work and a time for pleasure, and I do not mix both,’ he says.

‘It’s in my contract – no knocking on any doors!

‘I’ve had offers, don’t get me wrong.

‘But it would complicate things terribly, wouldn’t it?’

One of five children, Brendan grew up in a Roman Catholic household.

‘I had a lovely childhood, and I did a lot of Irish dancing when I was a kid because most Irish families had someone who played a fiddle or an accordion and I was the dancer,’ he says.

Like many Northern families at the time, his father worked in the industrial sector.

However, Brendan is proud of a link between his dad’s trade and his own eventual career in travel.

(Image: Supplied by WENN)

‘My dad was an engineer, he used to work for a company that produced blades for turbine engines,’ he recalls.

‘In fact, his company produced the turbine engines for Concorde.

‘He never got to fly on it, but I did.

‘I’m the only supersonic Sheerin in my family!’

The Sheerin clan may not have been jet-setters, but they always made the most of their holiday time.

‘Every year we decamped to Yorkshire or would go to my grandmother’s farm in the middle of Mayo, run havoc in the fields and have a brilliant six weeks of summer holidays,’ says Brendan.

‘The whole family would go.

‘At Easter my dad would get us a caravan in York and we’d go sightseeing.

‘The caravan would be right on the River Ouse, at Acaster Malbis.

‘We’d go fishing and have a great time.’

Brendan’s fans might be surprised to know that the king of coaches had his heart set on a very different vocation when he was younger.

If things had turned out differently, he could well have become Father Brendan.

‘I thought I had a calling to the priesthood when I was about 13,’ he muses.

‘I was an altar boy and I was one of the favourites because I could do everything, like the incense, or the Smoking Handbag as we called it.

‘I was brought up saying Mass, which in those days was in Latin.’

Brendan’s hopes for joining the church were taken seriously enough for bishops and priests to consult him and his father on it.

‘It was like a Vatican Council, there were all these priests asking me questions – did I do sports, what subject did I like at school?’ he remembers.

‘My dad wasn’t happy about it, I think he wanted me to go out and see a bit of life before I decided on celibacy and all that carry on.’

When Brendan is back in his home town he’s guaranteed to receive a good reaction.

‘I do still come home a lot, my family live in Leeds.

‘It’s not, “Oh it’s Brendan from Coach Trip,’ it’s, “Eee, it’s our Brendan!’’ he smiles.

‘The welcome I get is amazing because I was born and bred there.’

(Image: PLANET PHOTOS)

Although Brendan clearly loves his life in Spain, he always makes sure he tops up on home comforts when he’s back in the UK.

‘I’ll always eat Yorkshire pudding and roast beef when I’m back.

‘I have a fat rascal, which is a big fat scone, at Betty’s in Harrogate with my agent Paula.

‘I also love Galaxy chocolate.

‘My friends fly out to Spain with it, they have orders!’ he laughs.

His skill at helping the Coach Trip passengers to relax and enjoy the experience is one he learned very early on.

‘When I started as a courier in Spain I used to go to the airport every week and you’d have a Lord and Lady coming through alongside a miner from Barnsley.

‘Now, I couldn’t treat them any different, even though the Lady probably had seven hat boxes going round on the carousel with her luggage and the poor couple from Barnsley didn’t,’ he muses.

They say that if you choose a job you love then you’ll never work a day in your life.

Brendan obviously still gets a kick out of being a tour guide, but warns that it’s not for everybody.

‘You do have to be a people person to do the job that I do.

‘When it’s an industry dealing with people then you’ve got to be.

‘Otherwise don’t bother, get another job!’

How do you spend your Sunday?

■ Lie-in or up with the lark?

I sometimes have a quiet morning, a bit of a lazy day, but I do like to get up and swim in the pool in my garden or I might go to the beach for an hour or two.

I usually treat myself to an English newspaper, I like to read one at least once a week.

■ Telly or book?

I’ll watch NCIS but it’s mostly Spanish shows we get, and I do love reading historical non-fiction, I’ve got two on the go at the moment.

One’s called Catherine Of Aragon by Giles Tremlett, which is all about her life.

The other one is Cathedral Of The Sea by a Spanish writer called Ildefonso Falcones, which is all about building this church in Barcelona.

(Image: WENN.com)

■ Entertain or eat out?

I can cook. I’m a very good cook.

My signature dish would be Greek lamb cooked very, very slowly in the oven.

And I love fish, living on the coast.

Salmon, trout, you can get all that in Spain easily.

But I’ll often meet some friends for lunch, usually paella because you have paella on a Sunday.

In the evening I always go up to Malaga on the train and meet Bruno and Juanito, Pepe and all that lot.

We’ll have some tapas or churros con chocolate, then go for a walk around Malaga.

- Celebrity Coach Trip starts tomorrow, 7.30pm on E4, or catch up on All 4.
description: Legendary Channel 4 tour guide Brendan Sheerin, 60, tells all as he chats about the new series of Coach Trip - and how life has changed for young gay people
